thread.title: Sorority sisters' souvenir booklets cause delays at Texas airport security
thread.title_full: Sorority sisters' souvenir booklets cause delays at Texas airport security | Daily Mail Online

author: Becky Pemberton For Mailonline
title: Sorority sisters' souvenir booklets cause delays at Texas airport security
text:
5 shares 5
View
comments
They're books that look innocent enough - but to an airport scanner they're highly suspicious.
There was chaos at an airport in Texas last week when thousands of sorority sisters tried to bring souvenir booklets from a convention through security but were held up because X-ray machines could mistake them for bombs.
This is apparently down to the books' thickness and quantity of colour photos, which makes them look like plastic explosives.
Sorority's souvenir booklet causes big delays at airport Chaos was caused at an airport in Texas when thousands of sorority sisters tried to bring souvenir booklets from their latest convention through airport security
Long wait: Long queues formed at the airport in Texas as TSA officials checked the sisters' hand luggage
Out the door: The queues went out of the airport due to the increased security checks by staff
According to reports, the TSA at William P. Hobby Airport last Thursday had to check the majority of the sisters' hand luggage, causing hours of delays.
According to Khou , travellers who arrived at the airport found queues out of the door at the passenger drop-off area due to the increase in security checks.
'There were lines... wrapped around the corner,' flyer Angela Greene told the news site.
 Next Monaco, St Tropez... and now Mayfair: Glitzy London district... Hidden treasure! Breathtaking new Somerset cavern with rare... From blood-red waters to a geothermal spa (and one that... From Andy Murray's luxurious Scottish residence to Rio... Chaos: Passengers faced long delays at William P Hobby airport as flyers told how queues 'wrapped around the airport'
There were approximately 13,000 members of the Delta Sigma Theta Sorority​ in Houston for the sorority's 52nd National Convention, with many of them getting stuck in the delays at the airport
Passengers reported standing in line for three hours in the heat and some flyers missed their flights
There were approximately 13,000 members of the Delta Sigma Theta Sorority​ in Houston for the sorority's 52nd National Convention, with many of them flying out of Houston's oldest commercial airport.
'We stood in line for three hours in the heat,' Cassandra Tomes added to Khou .
'Our souvenir booklet, apparently it's too thick and because of all the coloured photos in it, it appears to look like some sort of plastic explosive.'
'I'm sure they were doing the best that they could, but it just wasn't enough.'
The delays were so severe that many of the waiting fliers missed their flights.
MailOnline Travel has contacted the airport for comment.
Passengers arriving at the airport were surprised to discover the chaos which was sparked by the book's thickness and quantity of color photos
Security staff at Hobby Airport in Houston conducted extra checks of hand luggage because the book sparked an alert
The journals are not the only unlikely items to have raised concerns at airport security.
A passenger flying from Newcastle Airport to Gatwick earlier this year was pulled aside at security after staff thought his pease pudding was Semtex, a plastic explosive.
A part-time actor was going through customs to board his EasyJet flight, when airport staff discovered he had six $2.80 tubs of the traditional pudding and North East delicacy in his hand luggage.
The boiled-legume dish was removed from his bags, along with several Greggs pies.
In addition to this, last year customs officers at Birmingham Airport seized a giant squash from a passenger who was trying to smuggle it into Britain from Asia.
The 4ft-long vegetable, which weighed in more than at 4st, was found with 175lb of fish and 94,000 cigarettes from Bangladesh.
A spokesman for Solihull Council said: 'It is a bit of a rare find, as you can imagine we do get cigarettes a lot, but not a squash, especially not one of this size.'
America's TSA (Transport Security Administration) even has an Instagram account where it documents the weird, and sometimes downright dangerous, items confiscated at security.
